Graphical abstract This review summarizes the main factors influencing the stability of 2D materials in electrocatalysis, and the corresponding improvement strategies. It also proposes other potential routes for developing 2D catalytic materials. In electrocatalysis, two-dimensional (2D) materials have attracted extensive interests due to their unique electronic structure and physical properties. In recent years, many efforts have been devoted to improving the catalytic activity of 2D materials. However, the stability of 2D materials under catalytic conditions, as a critical issue, requires better understanding for any practical applications. This review summarizes recent progress in electrocatalytic stability of 2D materials, including four intrinsic factors that affect the stability of 2D materials: 1. Weak interactions between 2D catalyst and substrate; 2. delamination of 2D catalyst layers; 3. metastable phase of 2D materials; 4. chemistry and environmental instability of 2D materials. Meanwhile, some corresponding solutions are summarized for each factor. In addition, this review proposes potential routes for developing 2D catalytic materials with both high activity and stability. Keywords 2D materials Electrocatalyst Stability 1 Introduction Electrocatalysis utilizes electricity to achieve effective chemical reactions, and is important for achieving clean chemistry and sustainable energy conversion [1–6]. The efficiency of the electrocatalysis reactions mainly depends on the properties of catalysts, which, ideally, should have both high electrochemical activity and long-term durability [7–13]. In recent years, two-dimension (2D) materials have been established as promising catalysts in a series of reactions due to the following reasons [14–19]. Firstly, 2D materials have all their atoms exposed at surfaces, thus providing larger active surface areas and higher mass activities (Fig. 1 a). For instance, Lu et al. incorporated one-atom-thick hBN onto NiFeO x H y [20]. Due to the high density of surface adsorption sites and the atomically-thin nature of the hBN film, the mass activity of hBN/NiFeO x H y surpassing that of commercial catalysts by five orders of magnitude. Song et al. discovered that monolayers of CoNi and CoFe layered double hydroxide (LDH) nanosheets exhibited increased active site exposure compared to their bulk counterparts [21]. As a result, these materials demonstrated superior catalytic performance for oxygen evolution reaction (OER). As shown in Fig. 1(b), the OER mass activity of CoS [22,23] and the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) mass activity of MoS2 [24] are correlated with their thicknesses. Excellent mass activity is shown when the thickness of material is reduced to a 2D morphology. Secondly, 2D materials could serve as an ideal platform for studying electrochemical reaction mechanisms due to their atomic-scale thickness and precisely defined surface structures. Electrocatalytic reactions usually occur at the interface between electrodes and solutions. For electrodes made of bulk materials, they exhibit catalytic behavior resulting from the coupled interactions between the interface, the surface of electrodes and the bulk of electrodes, making it challenging to analyze independently the surface effects of catalysts. In contrast, electrodes made of 2D materials have atomic-scale thickness and thus maximized surface effects for electrochemical reactions. Their precisely defined surface structures further facilitate the understanding of reaction mechanisms [25]. As shown in Fig. 1(c), Zheng et al. demonstrated a photoanode composed of monolayer InSe encapsulated by monolayer graphene [26]. The atomically thin electrode and its well-defined surface structure enable the observation of a strong coupling between hydroxide ions and photogenerated holes at the surface of electrode. Wang et al. fabricated monolayer MoS2 and WS2 heterojunctions (Fig. 1d) to investigate the dynamics of carriers between transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) [27]. Such structure avoids the complex carrier recombination effects presented in thick TMDs. Therefore, they discovered novel charge recombination and transport pathways in monolayer MoS2/WS2 heterojunctions. Thirdly, 2D materials can be assembled with each other to create heterostructures via van der Waals interactions. Compare to heterostructures formed by other materials, van der Waals assembly requires no lattice matching and processing compatibility, and thus is applicable across materials with various sizes, crystal structures and thus diverse electronic properties [28]. As shown in Fig. 1(e), 2D materials can form 0D/2D, 1D/2D, 2D/2D [29,30], and 2D/3D [31] heterojunctions with materials of various dimensions. These heterostructures not only combine the advanced properties of each component materials but also create catalytic systems with new functionalities. For example, Zhang et al. constructed a heterojunction consisting of monolayer carbon-doped boron nitride and monolayer graphene, as shown in Fig. 1(f) [32]. The interfacial Schottky barriers of the ultrathin nano-heterojunction promoted the separation of photogenerated electrons without involving long-distance charge-transfer paths. In addition, 2D materials are diverse and abundant with low cost of natural ores, and many of the raw materials used to prepare these materials are abundant in nature, such as carbon, sulfur, and transition metal elements, for example, MoS2, the global proven Mo reserves are about 500 times that of Pt, and its price is three orders of magnitude lower [33]. This lays the foundation for the large-scale application of 2D materials. Although the above advantages of 2D materials lead to wide range of application prospects, realizing the expected promises of these materials require better understanding of their stability in electrocatalytic environments. As shown in Fig. 2 (a), the current density and stability statistics of various 2D catalysts indicate that only a relatively small number of 2D catalysts are able to fulfil both high performance and high stability [34–45]. Therefore, it is essential to achieve a better trade-off between performance and stability, as shown in Fig. 2(b). In this review, we summarize the main factors influencing the stability of 2D materials in electrocatalysis, and the reported strategies to improve the stability issues originated from each factor (Fig. 3 ). By overcoming the balance between activity and stability, 2D materials are expected to drive advances in the fields of sustainable energy conversion and environmental governance. 2 Microscopic mechanisms and solutions affecting the electrocatalytic stability of 2D materials The stability of 2D material-based electrocatalysts is related to various factors which are divided into four main issues as summarized in Fig. 4 . Issue 1 is the weak interactions between 2D catalysts and their substrates, including the substrate corrosion and the detachment of electrocatalysts due to the generation of gas products that form bubbles between the catalysts and the substrates. Issue 2 is the delamination of the layered-structures of 2D catalysts. Issue 3 is the metastable phase of certain 2D materials. Issue 4 is the chemistry and environment instability of 2D materials, including intrinsic instability of 2D materials at extreme pH and self-redox at unsuitable potentials. In the following sections, we will discuss each of these factors, aiming to offer insights into the origin of instability in 2D catalysts. 2.1 Issue 1: Weak interactions between 2D catalysts and substrate At present, water electrolysis experiments in laboratories are predominantly carried out at room temperature [46–48], whereas industrial settings operate within the range of 50–80 °C [49]. Hence, for the experimental electrocatalyst to find industrial application, one must account for its mechanical stability under adverse conditions like high current density, prolonged operational duration, and elevated temperatures [50,51]. This is because the mechanical stability of a 2D material, when used as a catalyst or catalyst carrier, determines its lifetime and performance [34]. We know that the mechanical stability of 2D materials is affected by factors such as grain boundaries, cracks and cavities, and these defects especially affect the anisotropy of the mechanical strength of 2D materials [52]. In electrocatalytic reactions for gas production, the presence of defects may affect the durability of the material under the effect of mechanical stresses from bubble desorption and stresses generated during electrolyte flow [53–55], for example, leading to severe erosion or detachment of the catalyst surface, which is detrimental to the mechanical stability of the 2D material [56]. Meanwhile, in the two-phase interface, as bubbles nucleate, grow and eventually detach from the catalyst, although bubble detachment induces convection and promotes mass transfer to some extent, mainly, if the bubble detachment rate is very slow, it hinders active sites and blocks ion diffusion channels, which has a significant negative impact on the performance of the catalyst [57]. For instance, as shown in Fig. 5 (a, b), during the HER reaction, the high current density triggers the formation of numerous H2 bubbles by the 2D PtSe x electrocatalyst [37]. The subsequent separation of these bubbles engenders robust adhesion between the electrocatalyst and the bubbles [58–60]. The microscopic mechanism of bubble separation leading to catalyst detachment is shown in Fig. 5(c), where the electrocatalysts can be peeled off from the support when electrocatalyst-bubble adhesion force is larger than that between the electrocatalyst and support [61]. Therefore, it is important to improve the mechanical stability of the electrode by adjusting the interaction forces between the electrocatalyst and the substrate, and reducing the adhesion forces when the bubbles detach from the electrocatalyst. Meanwhile, the rapid desorption of small bubbles facilitates the efficient transport of active substances in solution to the electrode surface, maintaining the catalytic activity of the catalyst and improving the efficiency of the electrochemical reaction. Electrochemical corrosion of catalyst substrates also leads to catalyst detachment. Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) at the cathode often occurs under high potential and in strong acid or alkaline environments [62,63]. This leads to severe electrochemical corrosion of the carbon black support found in the widely used Pt/C [64,65], resulting in the dissolution or aggregation of surface Pt particles, thereby compromising the catalyst’s lifespan, as shown in Fig. 5(d). The microscopic mechanism leading to severe electrochemical corrosion of carbon black is as follows: under fuel cell on and off conditions, the local potential of carbon black, the support material of the cathode of the proton exchange membrane fuel cell (i.e., where the ORR occurs), rises above the operation potential, and a fuel starvation may occur under these conditions. As a result, in the presence of water and at a potential higher than 0.207 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE), the carbon thermodynamically undergoes the following corrosion reaction [65]. (1) C + 2H2O → CO2 + 4H+ + 4e− E 0 = 0.207 V vs. RHE At the same time, the carbon is oxidized to carbon monoxide (CO) (Eq. (2)), which is then further produced as carbon dioxide (CO2) in the presence of water. (2) C + 2H2O → CO + 2H+ + 2e− E 0 = 0.518 V vs. RHE (3) CO + H2O → CO2 + 2H+ + 2e− E 0 = − 0.103 V vs. RHE Furthermore, during electrochemical reactions, the intermediate products of oxidation, such as CO, are adsorbed on the surface active sites of the metal catalyst particles, which may lead to the loss of ORR activity of the catalysts due to the poisoning of catalytic sites by oxidized intermediates [65]. Considering the inadequate 2D catalyst-substrate combination, this review outlines the following three solutions. 2.1.1 Solution 1 to issue 1: Enhanced electrocatalyst-substrate adhesion Firstly, robust chemical bonds allow for enhanced connections between the substrate and the catalyst. Liu et al. induced in-situ reactions between MoS2 and copper, forming S–Mo and S–Cu bonds at their interfaces, thereby altering the adhesion strength at the interface between the electrocatalyst and the substrate [61]. Such Chevrel-phase CuMo6S8/Cu electrode enables stability for 100 h at a current density of 2500 mA/cm2, as shown in Fig. 6 (a). The critical factor in successfully enhancing catalyst stability lies in annealing the dried MoS2/Cu electrode in a mixture of Ar (200 sccm) and H2 (10 sccm) at 750 °C for 2 h to prepare the CuMo6S8/Cu electrode, as shown in Fig. 6(b). Notably, this method boasts two distinct advantages. (1) The absence of binders ensures the exclusion of additional factors that might disturb the electrocatalytic system. (2) The in-situ reaction between MoS2 and Cu effectively eliminates the energy barriers, as shown in Fig. 6(b). Yu et al. reported a highly stable Ta-TaS2 monolith catalyst with a robust metal interface [34]. This catalyst features vertically grown metallic TaS2 on a Ta substrate, exhibiting strong Ta–S covalent bonds at their interfaces. This structure fundamentally eliminates the issue of catalyst detachment under high current operation, ensuring no degradation even after 200 h at 1000 mA/cm2 current density. The electrode material binds strongly to the substrate through robust chemical bonds, resulting in a potent adhesion at the interface of the electrocatalyst and substrate. In contrast, a comparatively weaker binding interaction is observed at the interface of the electrocatalyst and gas bubbles. Secondly, choosing substrates with strong adhesion to the catalysts can avoid catalyst detachment. Tsai et al. investigated the effect of different substrates on MoS2 HER by theoretical calculations, as shown in Fig. 6(c) [53]. The calculations showed that Au (111) as the substrate can achieve an optimal hydrogen adsorption free energy close to 0 eV. This suggests that the hydrogen adsorption energy can be reduced by enhancing the coupling between the substrate and catalyst. As discussed earlier, in the electrolysis process, enhancing the firm attachment of the catalyst to the substrate can improve the mechanical stability of 2D electrocatalytic materials in the gas-generating electrocatalytic process. Yu et al. successfully synthesized 2D metallic TaS2 using chemical vapor deposition technique on four different substrates, including a glassy carbon, carbon fibers, and molybdenum and Au foils, to evaluate the influence of different substrates on the HER performance of TaS2 [66]. It was found in the experiments that TaS2 could be well anchored on Au substrate, and the lattice structure of TaS2 remained unchanged after 12 h of stability testing. Furthermore, TaS2 grown on gold foil exhibited the best performance, with the smallest overpotential and charge transfer resistance. These results underscore the importance of substrates in catalyst performance engineering. The above approaches can significantly improve the stability of electrocatalysts under high currents and prolong their lifetime by establishing strong chemical bonds or by choosing substrates with strong adhesion to the catalyst. The first approach doesnot use binders and therefore excludes other factors that may interfere with the electrocatalytic system. The second method relies on the selection of a suitable substrate, which may be required for different catalysts, limiting the generalizability of the method. 2.1.2 Solution 2 to issue 1: Accelerating the dissociation of bubbles from the electrode surface In electrocatalytic reactions that generate gas products, the gas bubbles keep growing before they have adequate buoyancy to detach from the electrode surfaces. Due to the adhesion between the 2D electrocatalyst and the bubbles, it may lead to the tearing of 2D materials during the bubbles’ detachment. The above situation is expected to be improved if the desorption of small bubbles can be accelerated and the adhesion between the catalyst and the bubbles can be reduced. To that end, two types of methods have been reported, as we summarized in the following. Firstly, altering the hydrophilicity of 2D catalysts through methods such as plasma surface modification hinders the growth of bubbles on the electrocatalyst surface and accelerates the immediate dissociation of the newly formed small bubbles. Guo et al. synthesized polycrystalline graphene films grown on Ni foil/Ni foam. Such polycrystalline graphene surface exhibited numerous domain boundaries and open edges, providing additional surface energy for the attachment and sustained expansion of bubbles [67]. This ultimately resulted in strong hydrogen adsorption behavior. In contrast, introducing a small amount of oxygen-containing functional groups such as –OH and –OOH on the graphene film surface via atmospheric pressure plasma treatment not only makes the graphene surface more hydrophilic but also introduces defects into the graphene film, while also eliminating sharp edges. This was manifested macroscopically by the expansion of invisible surface hydrogen gas bubbles, making hydrogen bubbles easily detach from the surface, as shown in Fig. 6(d). At a current density of 10 mA/cm2, it produces H2 bubbles stably and continuously for 12 h. Wang et al. synthesized Co-doped VSe2 nanosheets based on a colloidal synthesis method assisted by organic surfactants [68]. Subsequently, the surface hydrophilicity of the material was modified via AP treatment. As shown in Fig. 6(e), CA spectra before and after plasma treatment indicate successful modification. This treatment rendered the material surface more hydrophilic and less prone to bubble adhesion, suggesting successful weakening of the adhesion forces between the catalyst and bubbles. The less obvious decline in the current density was observed after 5000 cycles, demonstrating their outstanding stability. Secondly, construction of micro/nanostructures aids the rapid dissociation of gas bubbles to reduce the bubbles’ adhesion. Lu et al. utilized a hydrothermal method of vertically growing MoS2 nanosheets on the substrate to create a ‘water cushion’, as shown in Fig. 6(f), which decreases the adherence between bubbles and MoS2, serving as a ‘buffer layer’ [38]. The size of bubbles released from flat surface is 10 times of that from nanostructured electrode in diameter. Therefore, overlapped polarization curves before and after 1000 cyclic voltammetry (CV) cycles and similar charge transfer impedance were observed, indicating the high stability of nanostructured MoS2 film for HER. Similarly, Kuang et al. reported an in-situ topotactic reduction method using Ni(OH)2 array precursors to prepare atomic-thickness 2D nickel nanosheet arrays (Ni-NSA) [69]. In the hydrazine oxidation reaction (HzOR), such a structure engendered discontinuous three phase contact line and exhibited almost no adhesion force to gas bubbles, resulting in the release of small-sized bubbles and the rapid removal of formed N2 bubbles. Additionally, it was discovered that subjecting partially oxidized Ni-NSAs to low-pressure air conditions generates ultra-thin Ni/NiO-NSAs, which also exhibited a superaerophobic surface structure and retained good electrocatalytic stability. After 10 h of stability tests, the Ni/NiO-NSAs retained 94.9% of their initial current density, without structural damage observed. It should be noted that when talking about gas-involving reactions, such as carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR) and ORR, since their requirements for bubble dynamics and surface wettability are different from those of gas-generating reactions (HER, OER). Therefore, the method of accelerating the dissociation of bubbles from the electrode surface is only applicable to the gas-generating reactions (HER, OER). The reason for the above situation is that in the HER and OER, the high wettability of the electrode surface promotes the rapid desorption of bubbles and the transport of active substances from the solution to the electrode surface [70–75]. However, in the CO2RR, the electrode surface must be able to adsorb gas molecules efficiently and desorb them rapidly after the reaction [76–78]. Therefore, moderate hydrophobicity can usually help to enhance the adhesion of the gas on the electrode surface and thus increase the reaction rate. However, it should also be noted that excessive hydrophobicity may hinder the desorption of reaction products. In addition, in the ORR, the electrode material also needs to possess the characteristic of high hydrophobicity [79–81]. This is because a hydrophobic surface promotes efficient transport of oxygen to the electrode active site, which is essential for maintaining a high reaction rate. At the same time, hydrophobic electrodes help prevent the catalyst layer from being flooded with water, ensuring that the reactants remain accessible to the active site. 2.1.3 Solution 3 to issue 1: Switching to stable substrates rather than susceptible ones to corrosion Compared to carbon black substrate, graphene can act as promising catalyst substrates with superior stability, heightened conductivity, and larger specific surface areas, due to the distinctive sp2-bonded carbon atomic structure. However, the inert graphene surface lead to weakly attached other catalysts on their surfaces. To address these challenges, graphene is transformed into graphene oxide through the introduction of oxygen-containing groups, facilitating the attraction of Pt nanoparticles (NPs) [82,83]. Anwar et al. vertically grew 2D multilayered 2H-MoS2 structures on reduced graphene oxide (rGO), thereby exposing numerous active edge sites [84]. Subsequently, Pt was loaded onto these NPs to fashion Pt/MoS2-rGO heterojunctions, as shown in Fig. 6(g). In stability assessments, following 10,000 cycles of ORR, Pt/MoS2-rGO exhibited a 25% activity loss, showcasing a significant enhancement in stability compared to Pt/C which plummeted to 75% of its initial value. The heightened duration of Pt/MoS2-rGO can primarily attributed to the robust chemical and electrical bonding between MoS2 and reduced graphene oxide. Moreover, the potent interaction between MoS2 on the graphene oxide surface and Pt serves to anchor platinum NPs while impeding platinum aggregation. Similarly, Guo et al. demonstrated a wet-chemical techniques for synthesizing high-quality Pt-on-Pd bimetallic nanodendrites supported on graphene nanosheets (TP-BNGN) [85]. The experimental test results revealed that the I f/I b ratio (the ratio of the forward oxidation current peak to the reverse current peak) of TP-BNGN is 1.25, which is larger than those of the platinum black (PB) (0.95) and commercial Pt/C catalyst (0.70), indicating best catalyst tolerance of TP-BNGN. The CV cycling can be seen that the loss of the electrocatalytic activity for PB and catalysts is higher than those of TP-BNGN, further showing that the TP-BNGN has longest catalytic duration and the longest lifetime. This method uses graphene with good electrical conductivity, which helps to improve the electrocatalytic performance of the catalyst. However, the introduction of graphene oxide or graphene requires a complex preparation process, which increases the difficulty and cost of preparation. In order to more visually assess the effectiveness of each strategy, we summarize and quantify the information in Table 1 . 2.2 Issue 2: delamination of 2D catalyst layers The integration of 2D heterojunctions is achieved via vdWs interactions between each component of 2D materials [86], as shown in Fig. 7 (a). While vdWs interactions offer advantages as discussed earlier, they also present significant drawbacks that cannot be overlooked in electrocatalyst design. The strength of vdWs interactions typically ranges from 0.1–10 kJ/mol. Ionic or covalent bonds (approximately 100–1000 kJ/mol) are greater by 2–3 orders of magnitude [87], as shown in Fig. 7(b). Consequently, this may lead to the delamination of 2D materials with compromised stability during intense electrochemical reactions [56,88,89], as shown in Fig. 7(c). Its microscopic mechanism is that external factors (e.g., adsorption of gas bubbles or strong flow of electrolyte) can produce horizontal shear force or tensile strain on the 2D material. Although the introduction of stress and strain can enhance the catalytic performance of the material to a certain extent [90–92], it also leads to the local lattice deformation of the material and increases the local instability [93]. This further manifests as delamination or curling of the 2D material [56]. To address this problem, the following two solutions have been reported. 2.2.1 Solution 1 to issue 2: 2D superlattice for enhanced interlayer electronic coupling The major advantage of 2D superlattice materials for electrochemistry is that the electronic coupling between the two constructing layers can enhance structural stability and promote chemical or electrochemical activity [94,95]. Xiong et al. synthesized the superlattice-like assembly by alternately restacking modified reduced graphene oxide nanosheets and monolayer MoS2 (Fig. 8 a) [96]. Compared to the reported MoS2/graphene composite materials, the unique monolayer morphology, the favorable metallic 1T phase, and high overall conductivity can occur at the same time in the MoS2/graphene superlattice, as each MoS2 nanosheet is directly hybridized and stabilized by the modified reduced graphene oxide at the molecular scale. This leads to efficient and durable sodium storage and hydrogen evolution. As a sodium storage anode, it exhibits a stable reversible capacity of ∼380 mA h/g after 1000 cycles at 10 A/g. Similarly, Kwon et al. stacked graphitic-carbon nitride (g-C3N4) and MoS2 nanosheets alternately to form a superlattice material [97]. The interstratification of MoS2 nanosheets and g-C3N4 leads to strong interfacial electronic coupling, as shown in Fig. 8(b). Such a structure makes it show much superior stability than MoS2 in chronopotentiometry measurement within 10 h. Also, this structure can be used as a photocatalyst for visible light-induced N2 fixation. After 90 min of the N2 fixation test, the original X-ray diffraction pattern can still be maintained without impurity peaks, which indicates its high stability. This method prevents the material from interlayer peeling or destabilization during the process, but controllable stacking of 2D materials alternately to form a 2D superlattice material is difficult and requires overcoming complex preparation processes and interfacial issues. 2.2.2 Solution 2 to issue 2: Chemistry for enhanced interactions between 2D layers Chemical intercalation can adjust the electronic structure of 2D TMDs, thereby fundamentally enhancing their physical and chemical characteristic for catalytic applications [98]. Luo et al. synthesized a 2D MoS2 nanosheet material with intercalated Co(OH)2 NPs (denoted as Co-Ex-MoS2) through a two-step method, as shown in Fig. 8(c), which served as an electrocatalyst for water dissociation, exhibiting good durability even after 20 h of testing in alkaline solution [99]. The intercalation process involved dispersing the nanosheets in a solution of n-butyllithium (n-BuLi) in hexane, inserting lithium into the vdWs gap of exfoliated MoS2 nanosheets, yielding Ex-Li x MoS2. Subsequently, CoCl2·6H2O was added to a solution of N-methyl-pyrrolidone (NMP) to exchange Li+ in Ex-Li x MoS2 with Co2+. Similarly, Gunjakar et al. synthesized 2D Ni(OH)2 nanosheets and 0D polyoxovanadate (POV) intercalated structures using a bottom-up one-step chemical solution growth method (the intercalated nanohybrids were denoted as ‘NHV’), as shown in Fig. 8(d) [100]. The absorption peaks of the V–O–V chain and V=O in the Fourier transform infrared spectra confirmed the entry of POV ions into the interlayer space of Ni(OH)2. Such highly porous house-of-cards-type interconnected network morphological structures retained long-term electrochemical stability even after 25 h of chronopotentiometry, as shown in Fig. 8(e). This method is more flexible than the physical method because precise control of the material structure can be achieved by adjusting the chemical reaction conditions. However, the intercalation process may introduce some impurities or defects, which may affect the properties and stability of the material. Especially when not properly controlled, impurities may cause unexpected electronic structure changes and reduce the performance of the material. At the same time, the intercalation process requires precise operating techniques and conditions, and therefore may be less suitable for some large-scale preparations. Also, we summarize the solutions to Issue 2 in Table 2 . 2.3 Issue 3: Metastable phase of 2D materials TMDs, as typical 2D materials, exhibit a rich variety of phase structures (Fig. 9 a). The 2H-MoS2 is the most thermodynamically stable but has poor catalytic hydrogen production activity; 1T and 1T’ are thermodynamically less stable but their monolayers possess excellent HER activity. It is concluded that MoS2 achieves the advantageous shift in HER catalytic activity after transforming from the 2H to the 1T phase [101,102]. In electrocatalytic reactions, 1T-MoS2 is readily converted to the metastable 1T’-MoS2 with distorted octahedral coordination. Enyashin et al. previously suggested a stabilization mechanism rooted in the crystal field theorem [103]. In 2H-MoS2, the conduction band’s lowest point and the valence band’s highest point are predominantly formed by Mo 4d states. Conversely, in 1T’-MoS2, the positioning of the Fermi level is primarily influenced by the metallic Mo 4d states [103]. In the interpretation of crystal field theory, the Mo 4d states are divided into two groups in 1T-MoS2 and three groups in 2H-MoS2 (Fig. 9b). The Jahn-Teller effect results in the splitting of the triply degenerate t 2g (dxy, yz, xz ) orbitals into two sets of d-orbitals, with minimal differences in energy levels. The 2H phase behaves relatively stable because the d z 2 orbital is filled with two electrons. In contrast, partial occupancy of the Mo 4dxy, yz, xz orbitals results in a metallic ground state for 1T-MoS2, thereby reducing its stability. Tsai et al. investigated the stability and activity of 26 different TMDs in HER using DFT calculations with a thermodynamic descriptor-based approach [104]. There is a relationship between the surface stability and activity due to hydrogen binding on X (X = S or Se) atoms is the beginning stage in the desorption of X into H2X to form vacancies. Commonly, the strength of HX binding (ΔG HX) inversely correlates with the binding of H (ΔG H) to the chalcogen X. It confirms the agreement that catalysts with higher reactivity tend to be less stable. As shown in Fig. 9(c, d), this inverse relationship is observed across the basal planes of both semiconducting and metallic transition metal selenides and sulfides. The variations in slopes among these relationships arise due to the existence of states near the Fermi level in metallic TMDs in contrast to their semiconducting counterparts, along with the broader states linked with selenium atoms in comparison to sulfur. Since all ΔG H values on the surface exceed 0 eV, any approach aimed at enhancing H binding to boost activity inevitably results in a decline in the stability of the catalyst. In order to stabilize the metastable phase, this review summarizes two methods to solve this problem. 2.3.1 Solution 1 to issue 3: Coordination bonding to stabilize the active site of the metastable phase In order to stabilize highly active metastable phases TMDs, Kwon et al. fabricated a 2D hybrid heterostructure comprising 1T’-MoS2 and Fe-phthalocyanine (FePc) molecules, as shown in Fig. 10 (a) [105]. In particular, the fivefold coordination of FePc with the sulfur site of MoS2 stabilizes the Fe-N4 site during the ORR process. Furthermore, FePc forms charge transfer complexes with MoS2, thereby bolstering the stability of the 1T’-MoS2. As shown in Fig. 10(b), this hybrid structure not only outperforms commercial Pt/C in catalyzing the ORR reaction in pH = 13 electrolyte, but also exhibits higher stability (degradation rate after 20 h: 9.3% vs. 40%). And no noticeable change in current density was observed on FePc-MoS2 following the introduction of methanol into the electrolyte, indicating that FePc-MoS2 was mostly unaffected by the methanol crossover effect. Under the same conditions, a notable decline in current density was observed for Pt/C. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy showed that FePc molecules hybridized with MoS2 remained after 20 h of ORR, while FePc within carbon black underwent oxidation, resulting in the formation of oxide NPs. The long-lasting stability of FePc-MoS2 can be attributed to the superb stability of the hybrid complex. However, the introduction of organic complexes into the system is often limited by pH, e.g. in acidic environments, some organic complexes may undergo protonation reactions, especially ligands containing functional groups that can be easily protonated. The pH of the catalytic system needs to be carefully considered. 2.3.2 Solution 2 to issue 3: Electron donor to prevent phase transitions The electrons provided by the electron donor group fill the d-orbitals of the transition metal in the metastable phase to a half-full steady state, thus preventing its phase transition back to the 2H phase. Chen et al. studied both the hydrogen and various carbon-terminated functional groups [102]. They discovered that stabilizing 1T’-MoS2 is achievable through surface functionalization involving the formation of covalent S–C or S–H bonds, inhibiting its transformation back into 2H-MoS2. As shown in Fig. 10(c), when a hydrogen atom acts as an electron donor and binds to the MoS2 monolayer, the extra electron of 1T-MoS2 occupies the partially filled Mo 4dxy, yz, xz orbitals, thus enhancing stability by achieving a half-filled occupancy of these orbitals. Instead, the excess electrons of 2H-MoS2 fill the vacant 4dxz or 4 d x 2 - y 2 orbitals, thus forming a metal-like electronic structure and destabilizing the 2H-MoS2 nanosheet lattice. Thus, the H atom can act as an electron donor to destabilize 2H-MoS2 and stabilize 1T’-MoS2. And the carbon-containing groups has a similar effect. Thus, the phase stability was assessed using the total energy difference (ΔE) between the modified 1T’ and 2H-MoS2 calculated by DFT calculations [102]. Obviously, ΔE increases monotonically from negative to positive (Fig. 10d), with the sign of ΔE after 16.7% before 25.0%. Hence, the presence of carbon end functional groups in adsorption diminishes the energy gap separating the 1T’ phase from the 2H phase, thereby fostering the formation of a more stable 1T’ phase. This stability is achieved with a coverage of up to 25%. The research underscores that carbon-containing groups require less coverage by functional groups (approximately below 25%) on the MoS2 monolayer compared to the H group (33.3%) to promote the energetically favored 1T’ phase. Based on this, Li et al. presented a one-step hydrazine-assisted hydrothermal method for synthesizing 1T-phase-dominant MoS2 nanosheets [106]. Their findings demonstrate that as the 1T/2H ratio increases, the electrical conductivity of MoS2 experiences a notable improvement, leading to a substantial enhancement in its electrochemical HER catalytic performance. More importantly, the as-prepared 1T-phasedominant MoS2 demonstrates exceptional stability at room temperature, with no discernible phase transformation observed over a period of three months (Fig. 10e). Moreover, DFT calculations analysis unveils that the interactions between the N2H4 molecules in the hydrazine precursor and MoS2 are exclusively favorable for the 1T polymorph. This observation may elucidate its augmented thermal stability, attributed to the reduction of Mo ions facilitated by electron donation from N2H4. Therefore, the stabilization of metastable phase TMDs by the introduction of electron donors will facilitate the goal of achieving both high activity and high stability of 2D materials during electrocatalysis. 1T-MoS2 requires electron donors to stabilize its properties during electrocatalysis, in contrast to black phosphorus (BP), which needs to give excess electrons to stabilize its electrocatalytic properties by establishing strong interactions, such as covalent bonding, with the passivating material (e.g., the metal cation with more empty orbitals). Zhao et al. synthesized a titanium sulfonate (TiL4) ligand for surface coordination of BP (TiL4@BP). In the TiL4@BP structure, BP gives the entire lone electron pair to form a coordination bond with TiL4 [107]. In contrast to the severe degradation of bare BP, TiL4@BP nanoflakes exhibit excellent stability when dispersed in water for long periods of time (5 days) and exposed to air, with minimal degradation of light absorbance and photothermal properties. The electron donation strategy is equally applicable to stabilize MXenes materials in electrocatalysis. Zheng et al. doped boron on Mo2CO2 and W2CO2 MXenes, which exhibited excellent selectivity and stability in nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) [108]. The electron-donating effect of Boron can be optimized by adjusting the transition metal species in the MXenes substrate to obtain excellent stability and catalytic performance. Hao et al. constructed Ag-ZnO/Ti3C2T x mesoporous nanostructured catalysts, and the electron supply of Ag and the upward shift of the d-band center with respect to the Fermi energy level in the MXene-tuned Ag-ZnO interface contributed to the high selectivity of CO and stability, and the stable current density and selectivity were maintained during the stability test of up to 108 h [109]. Peng et al. constructed a single-atom Ru-Mo2CT x catalyst for nitrogen fixation reaction, and demonstrated that the single-atom Ru anchored on MXene nanosheets was an important electron donation in the N2 activation process [110]. Operando X-ray absorption spectroscopy and DFT calculations demonstrated that monoatomic Ru anchored on MXene nanosheets is an important electron supplying center in the N2 activation process, which not only promotes the adsorption and activation behaviors of the nitrogen catalysts, but also lowers the thermodynamic energy barriers of the first hydrogenation step. The introduction of electron donors into the system tends to apply only to phase control, but tends to change the 2D morphology of the material, and additional driving forces are needed to stabilize the 2D morphology [111]. In order to more visually assess the effectiveness of each strategy, we summarize and quantify the information about solution to Issue 3 in Table 2. 2.4 Issue 4: Chemistry and environment instability of 2D materials 2D materials boast an abundance of active sites on their surfaces, rendering them highly sensitive to pH, electrode potential, and environmental factors like water and air. For example, few layers of black phosphorus are rapidly oxidized and degraded by water or oxygen in environmental conditions [112]. Significant fluctuations in pH levels can trigger self-reactions of the catalyst, such as dissolution and corrosion. Similarly, an unsuitable potential window may induce redox processes within the catalyst, consequently compromising its stability during electrocatalytic process. Localized acidic environments resulting from sluggish proton diffusion between layers of 2D materials (NiFe LDH) pose a threat to catalyst integrity, leading to corrosion. Chen et al. identified that the too slow diffusion of OH− into the LDH interlayers during OER in alkaline solution results in a localized acidic environment within the interlayers [113]. This acidity subsequently triggers the dissolution of NiFe LDH (Fig. 11 a). The shift of the (003) diffraction peak to lower angles upon immersing NiFe LDH in KOH solution indicates an expansion of the interlayers in the [001] direction (Δd ≈ 0.03 Å), affirming the penetration of the electrolyte into the interlayer region. As shown in Fig. 11(b), the variation in solubility of Ni and Fe ions between phosphate and KOH electrolytes arises from the discrepancy in the diffusion rates of HPO 4 2 - ions. The slower diffusion rate of HPO 4 2 - prevents its effective integration into the laminar structure during electrolysis, thereby fostering a localized acidic environment within the internal structure. Consequently, this acidic environment accelerates the solubility rates of Ni and Fe ions. When NiFe LDH is used for OER in seawater, anions with higher concentration in seawater, such as Cl−, will compete with the original anions in the LDH interlayer, or even be replaced, resulting in the destruction of the layer structure [114]. High salt concentrations in seawater environments alter the solubility of LDH, and dissolved ions tend to recrystallize in high salt environments, potentially altering the interlayer spacing or blocking interlayer pores, which can lead to material failure. However, it has also been demonstrated by in situ X-ray absorption spectra that the presence of Cl− increases the valence state of Ni decreases the valence state of Fe and stabilizes the lattice oxygen. The specific adsorption behavior exhibited by Cl− in alkaline seawater environments can transform the lattice oxygen mechanism of the OER into an adsorbent evolution mechanism, which contributes to the enhancement of the stability and activity of the NiFe LDH [115]. The choice of electrolyte and applied potential window also affect the stability of 2D electrocatalyst. Chemically modified graphene showcases a myriad of electrochemical reductions stemming from its electroactive oxygen functionalities, owing to its extensive carbon–oxygen bonds. As shown in Fig. 11(c), Chua et al. delved into the reduction peak potentials of oxygen functionalities on graphene oxide (GO), revealing common reduction potentials: aldehyde groups around −1.0 V vs. Ag/AgCl, epoxy groups around −1.5 V vs. Ag/AgCl, and carboxyl groups around −2.0 V vs. Ag/AgCl [116]. Therefore, when selecting GO as a catalyst material, it is important to avoid studying electrochemical reactions at these potentials. Meanwhile, Bonde et al. revealed that in the typical acidic catalytic environment of HER electrocatalysis, the intrinsic oxidation potential of MoS2 stands at 0.6 V vs. normal hydrogen electrode, peaking at 0.98 V, as shown in Fig. 11(d) [117]. In addition, the electrochemical oxidation process mainly involves the conversion of MoS2 to MoO3, SO4 2− and S2 2− as determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. López et al. used a dedicated scanning flow cell combined with inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry to simultaneously monitor Mo and S dissolution products during HER process [118]. It was noted that regardless of any electrochemical testing means used, the fastest dissolution of Mo, around 50–100 ng/cm2, occurs when the electrolyte comes into contact with MoS2. This is attributed at a microscopic level to the high valence surface state of Mo (Mo5+O x S y and MoO3), which once exposed to an acidic electrolyte which dissolves upon contact with an acidic electrolytic solution. Notably, it’s not just MoS2 that undergoes intrinsic oxidation reactions; other group VIB TMDs also exhibit similar traits. The order of oxidation potentials is as follows: WSe2 < MoSe2 < WS2 < MoS2 [119,120]. Benck et al. determined the inert potential window for highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (HOPG) [121]. As shown in Fig. 11(e), the inert potential region spans from –0.55 and 2.06 V vs. RHE in 0.1 M H2SO4, –1.03 and 2.20 V vs. RHE in 0.1 M NaAc, and –0.72 and 1.94 V vs. RHE in 0.1 M NaOH. Therefore, HOPG is an ideal substrate material for numerous studies due to its wide inert potential window. Since catalyst materials are susceptible to self-dissolution or self-redox reactions under extreme test conditions, we propose the following method to solve this problem. 2.4.1 Solution 1 to issue 4: Encapsulation using electrochemically inert 2D materials 2D materials such as InSe and BP are not stable in electrochemical test systems, and rapid deactivation or degradation in the environment makes it impossible to give a true picture of the intrinsic electrochemical catalytic capacity. Encapsulation with chemically inert 2D materials such as hBN or graphene can isolate them from direct contact with the catalytic environment, and the atomically thin encapsulation layer does not impede the electron transfer process. The monolayer graphene lattice does not allow any molecules or atoms to pass through [122,123], so graphene encapsulation can avoid direct exposure of unstable 2D materials to test environments saturated with water and oxygen. Zheng et al. successfully prepared InSe/Graphene PEC photoanode [26]. In this 2D material heterojunction (Fig. 12 a), the chemically less stable InSe is covered by graphene. Furthermore, the atomically thin graphene, known for its optical transparency and high conductivity, notably amplifies light absorption and assists in the transport of charge carriers between ions in InSe and PEC solutions. As shown in Fig. 12(b), the fresh anode shows the J max is about 8.8 mA/cm2. After 1 month leaving in air, the anode shows the J max is about 8.4 mA/cm2, little variation (<5%) of their original value. As can be seen from the optical microscope, neither indium selenide nor graphene were visibly damaged after the test (Fig. 12c). Lu et al. utilized one-atom-thick hBN as an encapsulating agent for NiFeO x H y (Fig. 12d) [20]. This encapsulation strategy (Fig. 12e) effectively prevents direct interaction between reactive species and NiFeO x H y , thus mitigating the risk of dissolution and etchingcaused by localized pH fluctuations within the NiFe LDH structure [20]. Even under high current density, the hBN/NiFeO x H y electrode exhibits exceptional stability. As shown in Fig. 12(f), the current fluctuates less than 10% at j = 2000 mA/cm2 over a duration of 150 h. In contrast, the performance of bare NiFeO x H y declines by 30% after just 10 h of operation at a current density of 2000 mA/cm2. All these experiments corroborate the explanation of electrode stability and indicate that OER-related species react on hBN surfaces independently, without direct contact with NiFeO x H y underneath. As the thickness of hBN films increases from mono-atomic layer to six layers, the current density of hBN/NiFeO x H y catalysts decreases by about 10 times. This can be attributed to the increased electron tunneling barrier in thick hBN films, which scales exponentially with thickness [124]. Similarly, encapsulation of chemically inert 2D materials is universal and can be used to encapsulate other forms of unstable catalysts, such as transition metal NPs. The stable graphene-like layer shields the core from the harsh reaction earning it the analogy of ‘chain mail’ for catalysts [125]. The chain mail graphene-like layer becomes active due to electronic interactions between the core CoNi NPs and the graphene-like layer, alongside induced charge redistribution [126]. As a consequence, the graphene-like carbon layer integrates into the core, promoting the adsorption and dissociation of O2, thus initiating the ORR (Fig. 12g). The DFT calculation [126] examining the impact of chain mail layer thickness showed that the electrons from the core catalyst can penetrate up to three layers before the effect diminishes. However, if the chain mail layer is too thin, the core catalyst may not remain stable under harsh reaction conditions. Hence, in such scenarios, a double-layered graphene-like chain mail would provide a balance of catalytic stability and activity [125]. Lei et al. used highly active metal Sn as an example, successfully synthesized ultra-thin metal Sn quantum flakes confined within graphene layers through a spatially confined reduction method [127]. The sandwich-like arrangement between the ultra-thin metal layer and graphene ensures excellent long-term stability. X-ray absorption fine structure results revealed that, thanks to the protection provided by graphene, the synthesized ultra-thin metal Sn quantum flakes confined within graphene layers showed no oxidized states of Sn. Additionally, their coordination number was reduced compared to bulk material, which enables the effective stabilization of intermediates by the lower-coordinated Sn atoms in the ultra-thin metal Sn quantum flakes. In the end, the ultra-thin metal Sn quantum flakes confined within graphene layers exhibited a remarkable current density of 21.1 mA/cm2 and remained stable for 50 h under this condition in CO2RR. This performance surpasses that of graphene mixed with 15 nm Sn particles, 15 nm Sn particles alone, and bulk Sn by a factor of two, 2.5 times, and 13 times, respectively. When selecting an inert 2D material as an encapsulation layer, the thickness of the encapsulation layer needs to be considered, which often requires a careful assessment of the balance between catalytic performance and protective effect. 2.4.2 Solution 2 to issue 4: Optimization of electrochemical environment The stability of an electrode depends on its intrinsic electrochemical properties and tendency to reactions, regarding the electrolyte selection and the range of applied potential [25]. Yew et al. determined that the surface of g-C3N4 synthesized g-C3N4 materials lacks the ability to undergo electrochemical oxidation or reduction [128]. In the interval where g-C3N4 itself is not chemically reactive, different electrochemical reactions can be boldly selected for testing. For example, the addition of 10 mM ferricyanide, 10 mM ascorbic acid and 10 mM uric acid in PBS produces redox peaks in the potential interval where g-C3N4 does not react chemically. Fan et al. achieved efficient and stable electrocatalytic NRR by few-layer antimonene in K2SO4 [129]. Theoretical calculations show that K+ in the electrolyte increased the proton migration energy barrier in the interfacial water, which inhibited the HER reaction and improved the NRR selectivity while increasing the stability of the catalyst. Most of the above discussions are electrocatalytic reactions in liquid-phase environments, but in non-liquid environments such as all-solid-state lithium battery (ASSLB), the charging and discharging processes can cause deformation of both the positive and negative electrodes of the lithium batteries, resulting in poor contact between the electrodes and the amount of electrolyte. And the side reaction between solid-state electrolyte and lithium anode will lead to the failure of lithium anode, and the protrusion of lithium dendrites from the anode will cause short circuit. Based on the above points, we summarize below the strategies that can enhance the stability of 2D material-based catalysts under different catalytic environments. The high specific surface area of 2D materials can provide additional Li-ion conductive channels to enhance Li-ion transport. And the high mechanical properties of the 2D materials will improve the mechanical strength of the solid-state electrolyte, thus inhibiting the growth of lithium dendrites and extending the lifetime of the ASSLB. Wan et al. constructed Cu2SnS3@graphene/Li7P3S11 nanocomposite cathode, and the large specific surface area of graphene provided more sites for Li7P3S11 (LPS) electrolyte contact (Fig. 12h) [130]. And the low expansion coefficient of graphene can adapt to the volume change of solid electrolyte in charging and discharging, which inhibits the agglomeration of active materials. As shown in Fig. 12(i), it exhibits excellent rate capability and high-rate cycling stability, showing reversible capacity of 363.5 mA h/g at 500 mA/g after 200 cycles. Xu et al. doped BN into the electrolyte Li7P3S11 for solid-state lithium-sulfur batteries, and the addition of BN can partially isolate the lithium electrode from the electrolyte and improve the stability of the electrode–electrolyte interface [131]. The LPS battery has a capacity of 91.5 mA h/g, while 102.3, 185.4, and 147.6 mA h/g for that based on LPS-x wt% BN electrolytes (x = 1, 2, and 3), respectively, after 50 cycles. In order to more visually assess the effectiveness of each strategy, we summarize and quantify the information about solution to issue 4 in Table 3 . Consideration of the catalytic environment requires a good understanding of the physical and chemical properties of the material itself. In solid media environments, stresses may cause chemical bonds within the material to break, thus reducing stability. Moreover, not only the overall pH of the solution must be considered, but also the local pH in the limiting space of the 2D material is often subject to abrupt changes. 3 Conclusions and outlook In this review, we have summarized the factors affecting the stability of 2D materials-based electrocatalysts that have been reported in the past few years and the corresponding solutions for improvements. Although those approaches have effectively enhanced the stability of 2D materials during electrocatalytic reactions, we note that better understanding of the electrocatalytic stability of 2D materials still needs further experimental and theoretical efforts, which presents both opportunities and challenges in this field. (1) In addition to the factors summarized in the previous section, the reasons for the complicated catalysts degradation process are still under debate since the structures and properties of 2D materials are dynamically changing during electrocatalyst processes. In order to obtain dynamic information about the 2D materials during electrocatalysis, in-situ characterization techniques such as in-situ Raman [132], in-situ infrared spectroscopy, in-situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and in-situ synchrotron spectroscopies have been applied to monitor the surface structure, electronic structure and chemical state of 2D materials in real-time, revealing more critical information about the mechanism of electrocatalyst deactivation in 2D materials. For example, Huang et al. characterized the spatial scales of the lattice-deformation regions and charge-transfer regions occurring at the edges of bilayer MoS2 during the HER process by in situ electrochemical tip-enhanced Raman Spectroscopy [133]. The spatial scale of lattice remodeling gradually increases along with the negative shift of potential, which may lead to the elongation of Mo–S bonds or even bond breaking in the MoS2 edge region. To some extent, it provides direct evidence for the instability phenomenon of MoS2 in HER. (2) In gas-producing electrocatalytic reactions, strong gas precipitation can cause serious damage to the electrocatalyst structure of 2D materials. However, at this stage, the research on gas bubbles is limited to the modification of the electrode interfaces of 2D materials, and there is still room for further exploration of the flexible manipulation of underwater gas bubbles. Therefore, the focus of future research could be in the direction of hydrodynamics of electrolytes. Optimization of the electrolytic cell structure and the chemical addition of electrolyte components may also improve the stability of 2D materials by directional guidance of bubble desorption on the surface of 2D materials. (3) The large 2D materials family offers various ways of combining different materials into novel heterostructures to enhance their catalytic activity and stability. Nevertheless, to find out the suitable material combination from the various possibilities, experimental investigation of trial and error is expected to be time-consuming and costly [134]. Therefore, utilizing artificial intelligence (AI) methodologies [135] alongside high-throughput computing techniques [136] presents an accelerated approach for the discovery and assessment of stable electrocatalysts tailored for 2D materials. The synergistic integration of AI and high-throughput computing empowers precise adjustments to the structural configuration and elemental composition of materials, thereby enhancing their overall stability and electrocatalytic activity. (4) Since electrocatalytic reactions are highly susceptible to a wide range of potential environmental factors and it is difficult to capture instabilities in the dynamic process. Theoretical research and simulation offer significant advantages in studying the stability of 2D materials for electrocatalysis. By using DFT calculations [137] and molecular dynamics simulations [138], researchers can predict material stability under various electrochemical conditions and uncover degradation mechanisms and deactivation processes at the atomic level. Additionally, multi-scale modeling applies atomic-level insights to the macroscopic scale, accelerating the development of stable and efficient electrocatalysts. (5) Industrial applications are the ultimate home of electrocatalysts for 2D materials, so the key to the future lies in large-scale production. As early as 2020, Zhang et al. reported an inexpensive MoS2 mineral-based catalyst with excellent high-current-density hydrogen precipitation performance [33]. The production rate of the catalyst was one to two orders of magnitude higher than previously reported, while the price of the mineral was five orders of magnitude lower than that of commercial Pt electrocatalysts. The key to the future lies in the development of low-cost, efficient synthesis methods and scalable production processes, optimizing automated and continuous production processes and ensuring efficient material handling and recycling. In membrane electrode assembly electrolyzer applications, efficient and stable electrocatalysts need to be designed to optimize interfacial engineering and improve catalytic efficiency and transport performance. At the same time, the long-time stability and high-current–density performance of the electrocatalyst should be enhanced, high-performance materials should be integrated into existing systems, and cost-benefit analyses should be conducted. Huijie Zhu is a Master’s degree student in the college of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering of Xiamen University. She joined Prof. Yang Cao’s research group in 2022. Her research interests focus on chemical vapor deposition (CVD)-grown 2D thin film materials for electrocatalysis/photocatalysis. Youchao Liu is a Master’s degree student in the college of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering of Xiamen University. He joined Prof. Yang Cao’s research group in 2022. His research interests focus on electrocatalysis of 2D materials. Yongsen Wu is a Master’s degree student in the college of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering of Xiamen University. He joined Prof. Yang Cao’s research group in 2022. His main research interests include wafer-scale 2D material growth and its application in (photo) electrocatalysis. Yushan He is a Master’s degree student in the college of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering of Xiamen University. She joined Prof. Yang Cao’s research group in 2023. Her current research interests focus on key technologies for efficient hydrogen isotope separation based on graphene. Yang Cao received her Ph.D. degree of Physical Chemistry from Peking University in 2012. Then she did her postdoctoral in Manchester University from 2012 to 2017, working with Prof. Sir. Andre Geim (the Nobel Prize winner of 2010). Currently, she is a full professor in Xiamen University. Her research interests are based on two-dimensional van der Waals heterojunction, including their application on optoelectronics/ photocatalysis, (electro) catalysis, micro-nano devices etc. Sheng Hu is a professor at the College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering at Xiamen University. He received his Ph. D from the University of Manchester in 2014, and worked as a research associate at the National Graphene Institute UK from 2014 to 2018. His research focuses on mass transport at nano- and angstrom-scale confinements, with more than 30 publications in Nature, Science, Nat. Nanotechnol., Nat. Commun. et al.

coredata.dc:description: In electrocatalysis, two-dimensional (2D) materials have attracted extensive interests due to their unique electronic structure and physical properties. In recent years, many efforts have been devoted to improving the catalytic activity of 2D materials. However, the stability of 2D materials under catalytic conditions, as a critical issue, requires better understanding for any practical applications. This review summarizes recent progress in electrocatalytic stability of 2D materials, including four intrinsic factors that affect the stability of 2D materials: 1. Weak interactions between 2D catalyst and substrate; 2. delamination of 2D catalyst layers; 3. metastable phase of 2D materials; 4. chemistry and environmental instability of 2D materials. Meanwhile, some corresponding solutions are summarized for each factor. In addition, this review proposes potential routes for developing 2D catalytic materials with both high activity and stability.
